snakespit

Each man paid 10 get back 1 that means each man paid 9 , 9 times 3 men plus the 2 the clerk pocketed should equal the original price of the room.
 
 Why cant you work this out and get the right answer?

 Because the above statement is incorrect. As it was originally written, the money is all accounted for. 
 $30 initially paid. 
 $25 actual bill.
 $3 returned to customers
 $2 kept by clerk.
 25+3+2=30
 
 If they had payed $9 each, it would have been $27 total and there would not have been a total of $30 initially. If the bill was still $25, the clerk would still have the $2 to pocket. You are mixing 2 different equations, which is why it appears to come out uneven. 
 
 :) (almost forgot the smiley)

post_info.post_title: A moment of science in remembrance of our beloved Monster.

Rovdak

Three men walk into a hotel.
 
 They want to share a room to save money.
 
 They ask the clerk how much he says 30.
 
 They each pull out a 10 and give it to the clerk.
 
 The three men go to there room.
 
 The clerk realizes he has over charged them by 5. 
 
 He thinks to himself how will I dived 5 by three!
 
 He decides to give them back 3 and puts 2 in his pocket instead.
 
 Each man paid 10 get back 1 that means each man paid 9 , 9 times 3 men plus the 2 the clerk pocketed should equal the original price of the room.
 
 Why cant you work this out and get the right answer?

 
 Because your closing statement is mathematically unsound 
 
 The first calculation is: 3*$10 =$30, where 3 is the amount of customers
 
 The second: 3*$9=$27 ($25 for the room +$2 the clerk pockets)
 
 Correct statements would be: 9 times 3 men plus the $3 the clerk returned should equal the original price of the room.
 
 Or: 9 times 3 men minus the 2 the clerk pocketed should equal the new price of the room.
 
 :p
